description:
Sclerotinia sclerotiorum 1980 UF-70 is a strain of the fungal pathogen Sclerotinia sclerotiorum, which is a necrotrophic fungus that causes a disease known as white mold or Sclerotinia stem rot in a wide range of agricultural crops, including soybean, canola, sunflower, and various vegetable crops.

The 1980 UF-70 strain was isolated in 1980 from a soybean field in the United States. It is a well-studied and widely used strain of S. sclerotiorum in research, particularly for investigating the biology, genetics, and pathogenicity of this fungus.

Sclerotinia sclerotiorum is known for its ability to produce sclerotia, which are hard, black, irregularly shaped structures that can survive in the soil for several years and serve as a source of inoculum for new infections. The 1980 UF-70 strain likely possesses this characteristic, which contributes to its persistence and ability to cause recurring outbreaks of white mold disease in affected crop systems.

Understanding the biology and host-pathogen interactions of the 1980 UF-70 strain has been valuable for developing effective management strategies to mitigate the impact of Sclerotinia stem rot on agricultural production.
